adr_address: V. Tommaso Grossi, 1, 20121 Milano MI, Italy

editorial_summary.overview: Elegant rooms & suites in an upmarket property featuring a cafe, a renowned restaurant & a spa.

formatted_address: V. Tommaso Grossi, 1, 20121 Milano MI, Italy
name: Park Hyatt Milan

plus_code.compound_code: F58Q+4G Milan, Metropolitan City of Milan, Italy

reviews.text:
I would say this was the best hotel experience I’ve ever had—not just one of the best, but truly the most enjoyable.

Park Hyatt is always known for luxury, but the Milan property is on another level.

During our month-long trip across Europe (France → UK → Italy), we stayed at Park Hyatt hotels in Paris and London as Globalist. Milan, however, stood out the most. The team was outstanding! From the moment we arrived, the concierge gave us a warm welcome and even remembered our names throughout the stay. I also highly appreciated the front desk staff, who went the extra mile to fulfill my request for a room with a vanity table. After weeks of traveling, having a spacious bathroom and closet was exactly what I needed to refresh—doing my nails, tidying up, and enjoying a relaxing bubble bath.

We stayed 4 days and 3 nights, trying the restaurant for a birthday dinner, the bar for happy hour, and of course their signature breakfast. Every experience was excellent and reflected the best of Italian hospitality—stylish, warm, and full of character.

No wonder so many people say Park Hyatt Milan is the best in the group—I couldn’t agree more, and I’d highly recommend it to anyone visiting the city.

I visited the Park Hyatt in Milan for lunch with my family, and the experience was extremely disappointing. From the moment we were seated, the service was shockingly poor. It took ages just to be handed menus, while other tables who arrived after us were quickly served and attended to.

The restaurant wasn’t even busy, so there was no excuse for the delay. What made it worse was the clear difference in how we were treated compared to other guests—it felt borderline racist. We were made to feel invisible. My young son was hungry and restless, and no one made any effort to check on us or acknowledge the situation.

My wife voiced her complaints directly to staff, making it clear that we were unhappy with how we were being treated. Despite this, no one seemed to care. Even the manager, while polite, offered no genuine apology or meaningful resolution.

Eventually, we had no choice but to walk out. We went to enjoy lunch elsewhere—somewhere we were treated with basic respect.

This kind of experience is unacceptable at any establishment, let alone one carrying the Hyatt name. If you’re a family or a guest from a diverse background, I strongly urge you to consider other options when in Milan.

Park Hyatt Milan was hands down the best hotel we stayed at during our time in Italy. From the moment we arrived, the service was impeccable — the doormen were attentive and welcoming, the front desk and room service teams were top-tier, and housekeeping kept everything spotless and perfectly maintained.

The rooms were absolutely beautiful — elegant, spacious, and thoughtfully designed. Breakfast each morning was a delight, with high-quality offerings and great service to match.

If I had one wish, it would be for a larger gym, but that’s a small note in an otherwise flawless experience. Highly recommend for anyone looking for refined luxury and world-class hospitality in Milan.

We stayed several nights and had an excellent experience.  Bathrooms with high end luxuries as expected including soaking tub and shower. Bidets in the room. We dined at several Michelin star restaurants during our time in Milan and the breakfast at the hotel was still a highlight. The staff go out of their way to be helpful and welcoming. Most impressive was a conversation with the bartender who opined about how well they are treated as staff by the general manager, especially during the remodel and shutdown over the pandemic. Got the sense that they really believe in the hotel and their service. Would recommend without reservation.

Pretty decent? There’s no lobby basically, breakfast is pretty simple. Came on Guest of Honor but no upgrade (I think hotel was pretty fully booked). Guest room was tiny like what you might imagine from a European hotel. Housekeeping is probably the only stand out here. Bed linens.
